pros: I loved my time at Unite Here, doing canvassing work. The work is meaningful and rewarding, and the management, depending on who you get, can be incredibly accommodating and understanding. I cannot emphasize this enough. When the work is good, and you click with it, it's great. Job security is great. The pay, for how easy it is to apply, is amazing. You learn a LOT throughout the entire process and get the ability to create new connections. It was also good for students, and the leads had custom schedules for the students.
cons: If you don't do well, leadership WILL let you know. Your leadership will change all the time if you work there for more than two months. Leadership can be incredibly secretive. Numbers are incredibly important. Here's a few things I noticed/incidents that are important to note -Transphobia: two trans employees were consistently misgendered by certain team leads. -Someone had apparently brought evidence that an employee had S/Aed someone outside of work. In response, the employee moved teams and nothing else, since the election was coming up and they needed as many canvassers as possible. -After a few months of working here, I noticed that employees stopped taking breaks. At training, they no longer told employees about their legal right to take their two 15 minute breaks. -A sign went up discouraging people from taking their breaks, for the sake of numbers and the people.

pros: Opportunities for growth and upward movement Respectful treatment at work People here really believe in and work hard for the mission of empowering workers. I feel like I am contributing to making change in the world. The benefits are amazing - better than anyone else I know.
cons: It can get very, very busy!

pros: Working on meaningful campaigns and member services
cons: A lot of work and no pay burnout

review_title: Loved it for many years but stress had me moving on
pros: The work is very meaningful. The community you develop is wonderful. The benefits are great.
cons: The hours are long and there isn't a lot of flexibility. For example if you had to work the full weekend you couldn't then make up a day or two during the week by taking it off unless you used a personal day and you had to get that approved which often was hard.

pros: Good interaction with the entire union
cons: nothing to really complain about

pros: This is Life changing work
cons: There are Long hours and work on holidays

job_title: Lead Organizer in New York, NY
pros: Great teams, bettter work life balance and work culture than SEIU.
cons: Long Hours, organizing is difficult

review_title: Hard Work but well worth it
pros: They believe in training and development and do it
cons: the pay scale is low

pros: Great place to work for
cons: They have a great work culture

pros: Great work environment and benefits
cons: the cons of working here is

pros: Learn to organize in real ways on the ground with urgency
cons: Unite Here is the worst employer I ever worked for. They are more racist, more exploitative, and play favorites worse than any other place. White supremacy is rampant. Tokenization is rampant. They are the classic example of a progressive and extractive culture. Loyalty over everything is the organizing model, in turn it makes the culture equally toxic as the top of the locals.

pros: A lot of great people work at this company that makes work really worth while
cons: Their structure is a bit outdated and patch work, not all departments, but enough to really affect everyone

review_title: Not POC friendly. Think I’m lying? look at leadership structure of every local. Even Las Vegas!
job_title: Token Minority in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They do very good work. If your POC you will be forward facing (i.e. members, community, politicians, developer reps. even media) and get opportunities to learn which is very advantageous.
cons: The trick is to learn when you have topped out and fearlessly move on. Listen to me: You will never get a true opportunity to lead, never. Be savage about it leave to greener pastures when you have learned all, avoid cliques, don’t drink the kool-aid.

job_title: Research Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: worker organizers are inspiring colleagues
cons: Absolutely terrible leadership. No regard to worker mental health. Incredibly abusive and inappropriate work culture. Leadership is all white and does not care about the workers they claim to serve. One of if not the worst union to work for.

pros: Great work environment, friendly coworkers, great benefits
cons: Routine work that can be boring at times

pros: There is no good reason to work for a manipulative organization.
cons: Manipulative, low salaries, bad managers

pros: Great mission. Lots of passion for making life better for working people.
cons: Long hours, low pay, high stress and an ever increasing workload.

pros: Organizing workers to fight back
cons: There is still a need for organizers because workers don't control the economy.

review_title: I love the work I did here
pros: Amazing benefits, critical work in the South, working directly with members
cons: Relatively low salary compared to similar positions

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: really incredible community of driven, passionate organizers
cons: some inconsistent leadership, but overall great people

pros: The people are wonderful and committed, inspiring, diverse, and fighting to make a better world and a better labor movement. The benefits are excellent. Leadership skills are prioritized and people who aren't good at leading other people generally don't get promoted. In the city where I was located, everyone had a lot of fun together at work and out of work.
cons: You need to be pro-active about making time for yourself that you need, as in most mission-driven work. If you struggle with this, you will struggle here. It's a scrappy place and I think people who are happy here generally enjoy jumping in and getting your hands dirty with whatever needs to get done. If that bothers you, you will be endlessly frustrated. If you don't want to be married to your work at least somewhat, this is probably not a good fit (in most positions--some admin positions are different and have more work-life balance).

review_title: Great benefits, no room for growth
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The organization offers great benefits and, generally, good job security.
cons: The pay is consistently low. Because of the organization's reluctance to let go of employees, especially those that have been there for years, there are a number of people who are inefficient, bad at their jobs, and bad managers. There is also no employee review process, so pay increases are decided on a whim. Depending on the department, there is very little room for growth.

pros: UNITE HERE thinks that it is the most radical and exciting labor union in the country, and in my experience it actually is.
cons: Too many staff in leadership positions do not come from the community and take a white savior approach to the work. BIPOC staff frequently get burned or pushed out after a relatively short period of time.

pros: Flexible schedule, real interest in developing employees' skills, opportunity for promotions, opportunity to travel, meaningful work, very hands on, etc.
cons: The hours are very long.  Management uses this as a badge of honor to push their employees instead of trying to instill a good life/work balance.  If you work for the international, you will also end up traveling a good deal.

pros: Good benefits and good pay - parking reimbursements for downtown.
cons: Leadership lack of knowledge in running a successful business

pros: It was a good job for a long time. I got to help lead lots of good fights for workers rights and the pay and benefits were good.
cons: Crazy hours. Chaotic internal culture with lots of infighting. Poor workplace stability.

pros: Amazing, talented, committed people and a fantastic organization, if a bit small.
cons: The projects are difficult and success is rare.

pros: Company paid fringes.  The catch is you will get sick by the toxic work environment.
cons: Undesirable working conditions.  Extremely long and unpaid hours. Verbal abuse by superiors were not dealt by management even though proper complaints were brought to their attention. High turnover rate.

pros: Cutting edge of labor movement. Good people.
cons: Low pay, and limited resources.

pros: It is very rewarding work as you learn how to become an organizer and the staff really cares about their workers
cons: Long hours, pay, and they need more staff of color.

pros: You get the opportunity for hands on organizing with workers, with constant training and team support.
cons: The hours are long, and the pressure for organizers to push workers is very intense.

pros: Feeling as though I have a part in empowering the powerless. gratifying on that level.
cons: Terrible work life balance, low pay and heavily political.

job_title: Accounting Manager in New York, NY
pros: diversified organization provide health benefits and pension to qualified local union members
cons: administration staff belongs to non collective bargaining unit/local

pros: Best place to grow and prosper with right team
cons: Management is stressful but not as much

pros: Working for a good cause
cons: Long hours and low pay

pros: Staff is dedicated and uncompromising in their work.
cons: Intense hours and high expectations from leaders.

pros: radical, exciting work. great learning experience. good people.
cons: low pay, heavy workload, high stress

pros: The only valid thing to work for this organization is your benefits
cons: No job growth, no incentive, management has poor communication, and no consist training.

pros: Getting to meet good people (staff, NOT leadership).
cons: Staff is overworked, underpaid, and not recognized for their efforts. Lots of mandatory "volunteer" work. Lots of intimidation and manipulation by leadership.
